1C9CC74A7E3D460E9FAFD02FBE2294EC.description: Evaluate data that supports the theory that rapid climate change is occurring due to human impact

8F465DBFA9D64B0BB3AD86EF8A6427F2.description: Discuss and evaluate the significance of human interference with major ecosystems (e.g., the loss of genetic diversity in cloned crops or animals)

EF17A5488C9D46ECAAE17D15C2C3ADCB.description: Read and describe current journal articles relating to environmental concerns (e.g., loss of biodiversity, habitat loss, pollution)

774495EBAF314350AE0EB61EB98B15D6.description: Explain the process of ecological succession, and describe the different communities that result

7753041C26A44C1EB30CE3A3F0DE8739.description: Describe the growth of populations, including exponential and logistic growth (e.g., design and conduct an experiment investigating bacterial growth using appropriate calculations)

86A647E1C40A4BC0AE9D538DE4A5EF0A.description: Explain the concept of carrying capacity

C1FEB4E455814EBEA0F0BEE988324C62.description: Describe examples of competition, symbiosis, and predation

5ED95A5FB8C2437BA827D2373C49DEBB.description: Diagram the flow of energy using food webs, food chains, and pyramids (e.g., pyramid of energy, pyramid of biomass, and pyramid of numbers)

895897237FDF487F970CAFACFEE1B7E6.description: Explain how organisms cooperate and compete in ecosystems and how interrelationships and interdependencies of organisms may generate ecosystems that are stable for thousands of years

4BEA47AAFD164D4890E65BD328C50336.description: Explain how the amount of life any environment can support is limited by the available matter and energy and by the ability of ecosystems to recycle the residue of dead organic materials

A1C9A2B789BC48C080C497EF1B5FA8E4.description: Explain how energy flows through ecosystems in one direction, from photosynthetic organisms to herbivores to carnivores and decomposers

74920B4316F94E9584F2C57619C57386.description: Discuss the role of beneficial bacteria (e.g., in the recycling of nutrients)

3303740929E44F0A9E3DAECF91043459.description: Discuss biotic and abiotic factors that affect land and aquatic biomes

E7707E53291F4DCCBFDE4FA99A24A37F.description: Define and provide examples of biosphere, biome, ecosystem, community, population, species, habitat, and niche

CACD2D53E2C0488E952F3B7F7AB3AAE8.description: Describe species relationship by using a phylogentic tree as a model

766CDF7A573748DCA474DBEECDE86DA9.description: Describe the post-zygotic barriers that prevent hybrids from becoming a species.

72B7869AC8344BCD9177EB103489DC9F.description: Specifically describe the conditions required to be considered a species, pre-zygotic barriers (e.g., reproductive isolation, geographic isolation)

C69423C9C3334A87BDBF703849FEC3CB.description: Provide examples of behaviors that have evolved through natural selection (e.g., migration, courtship rituals)

CCBD5ED216AA47F4A98AEB4898B9F417.description: Describe the basic types of selection, including disruptive, stabilizing, and directional

4130012757A04F13A93E644100228A62.description: Design, perform, and analyze a laboratory simulation of natural selection on a working population (moths)

FD55F26F518646B9AD8A6EE480D9B496.description: Explain how Earth’s life-forms have evolved from earlier species as a consequence of interactions of (a) the potential of a species to increase its numbers and (b) genetic variability of offspring due to mutation and recombinations of DNA

99DDC934D55043B3B16069BB87DFC89A.description: Explain how natural selection and its evolutionary consequences (e.g., adaptation or extinction) provide a scientific explanation for the fossil record of ancient life-forms and the striking molecular similarities observed among the diverse species of living organisms

D281DF38C5054777B135FCF3F5AAAC2E.description: Discuss evidence from the fields of geology, biochemistry, embryology, comparative anatomy, and comparative physiology that points to shared evolutionary relationships

048E2882F3064144AC3FA737028394C6.description: Explain the biological definition of evolution

9B41B133CCFE42B0827B922C44087313.description: Discuss Darwin’s four postulates of natural selection

EE2810883CA247408DFAA955F960C2AF.description: Contrast Lamarck’s and Darwin’s ideas about changes in organisms over time

C37CB162BBA34122946F9B6190C69524.description: Explain the influences of other scientists (e.g., Malthus, Wallace, Lamarck, Lyell) and of Darwin’s trip on HMS Beagle in formulating Darwin’s ideas about natural selection

A1D8BA59F3CD405FA17343FC777752E9.description: Support or falsify the hypothesis of spontaneous generation, looking at experiments performed by scientists like Miller and Urey

D763778BB2074EAFB18E036A7EF36895.description: Describe how gene expression is regulated in organisms such that specific proteins are synthesized only when they are needed by the cell (e.g., allowing cell specialization)

88354D32A602426999CBA1EC6829C19B.description: Use mRNA codon charts to determine the effects of different types of mutations on amino acid sequence and protein structure (e.g., sickle cell anemia resulting from base substitution mutation)

0F5ACEF952DD4156A67AD604EB6C5965.description: Describe the different types of mutations (silent, missense, nonsense) and their impacts on an organisms structure and function

84C010B461BD48FEA31E92DEB0892993.description: Use mRNA codon charts to determine amino acid sequences of example polypeptides

0937AD567526484AB2FF91A1AE20FBF3.description: Describe the role of the ribosome in process of translation, including descriptions of tRNA, amino acids, polypeptides, and proteins

4E8F1C5B399B4A8C99E7DCC54EE50F06.description: Describe the process of transcription, including the roles of mRNA and RNA polymerase, and that it occurs in the nucleus.

60CEC82F05D44A52879D5621A1E0B2AE.description: Describe the experiments of major scientists in determining both the structure of DNA and the central dogma

00E9C5C4A506433BBA04DE28ED333F7A.description: Describe the basic structure and function of DNA and RNA.

3F54F518D4FB41C893192AD0878B471F.description: Explain  how recombinant DNA, cloning, stem cell research, CRISPR are being used a genetic engineering tools

FFF600809FD640D2B4471645D1825CFF.description: Explain sex-linked patterns of inheritance in terms of some genes being absent from the smaller Y chromosome, and thus males (XY) having a different chance of exhibiting certain traits than do females (XX)

2FDD252EE69340D6B131B8129B52D6FC.description: Describe the mode of inheritance in commonly inherited disorders (e.g., sickle cell anemia, Down syndrome, Turner’s syndrome, PKU)

897C658BDA2647349213B1F23E153FC5.description: Infer parental genotypes and phenotypes from offspring data presented in pedigree charts and from the phenotypic and genotypic ratios of offspring

05C04005443C4614B1741761271FEC36.description: Construct and interpret Punnett squares and pedigree charts (e.g., calculate and predict phenotypic and genotypic ratios and probabilities)

E45012A581EA4700A2BA1C74AE9EF9B2.description: Define and provide an example of the following: genotype, phenotype, dominant allele, recessive allele, codominant alleles, incompletely dominant alleles, homozygous, heterozygous, and carrier

CD02C058218B49378F4DA90FFFF9D301.description: Explain how the process of meiosis reveals the mechanism behind Mendel’s conclusions about segregation and independent assortment on a molecular level

5BF208FCCBF94E729FCE73AFCFAE5EDB.description: Identify and explain Mendel’s law of segregation and law of independent assortment

1B02C469CDFA4EB8A2EDDC59BE71225D.description: Describe the process of meiosis, including the steps

83D50EBDEFD74A30BC3CD73BFEBFB279.description: Explain how a mutation in DNA that promotes an overactive cell cycle can lead to cancer

5DF6CA503AA6490FB05EE64CC9197F6B.description: Describe carcinogens that can increase the likeihood of developing cancer (cigarettes, lead paint, etc.)

F8F7CF6957334571A24D2C283CE3DDF3.description: Explain how the cell cycle is regulated by checkpoints.

F7E4EF197C0C4AF09E6423A3D5943388.description: Describe the process of mitosis, including the steps.

EF1BD3C41DBD4C32B0C5DDB4C7B068CA.description: Describe DNA replication, which occurs in the S phase of interphase

E8D714E723E447EC8387F693D329DD31.description: Describe the process of interphase and how it occurs before both mitosis and meiosis

FA919F420F294A9CAE51412B8DB9D1F3.description: Identify the cellular sites of and follow through the major pathways of anaerobic and aerobic respiration, compare reactants and products for each process, and account for how aerobic respiration produces more ATP per monosaccharide

921101A948F74B3F8E11A0A5BCBD2D25.description: Explain how cells store energy temporarily as ATP

080287848D114CA98D1EB873B6E52431.description: Design and conduct an experiment demonstrating effects of environmental factors on photosynthesis (light vs. dark)

50005EE151DD4DFDAC352103C4FF2510.description: Relate the products of the light-dependent reactions to the products of the light-independent reactions

AB8AF9F08CDD4059A32131822AED5225.description: Describe the light-dependent and light-independent reactions of photosynthesis

193E8E040B1549A09612DB61001D5A0E.description: Explain the interaction between pigments, absorption of light, and reflection of light

D9E10C8BA47448C0890D629AAE3EEF63.description: Explain how photosynthetic organisms use the processes of photosynthesis and respiration

BE04B6EDEC7C453D90B3CCB2DB867666.description: Describe the function of enzymes, including how enzyme-substrate specificity works, in biochemical reactions

AC9E3848B90147698473FFD08271A5BF.description: Show how chemical reactions (e.g., photosynthesis, fermentation, cellular respiration) can be represented by chemical formulas

26A171FCB71343858A3F421F67F9BBC0.description: Identify the difference between how an animal and plant cell behave in a hypotonic, hypertonic and isotonic solution

CCF1BE59D227413EA253B717018B07FC.description: Describe and contrast these types of cell transport: osmosis, diffusion, facilitated diffusion, and active transport

E35CAACA48DD4F82B23A1E5ADF47FCE2.description: Explain how the cell membrane maintains homeostasis

6511FDE82DC84282A32A77A2256BF540.description: Explain how the cell membrane controls movement of substances both into and out of the cell and within the cell

203E9AF3A9A04F938B5A55E16A7C5EC7.description: Contrast the structure and function of subcellular components of motility (e.g., cilia, flagella, pseudopodia)

6D2751F935F74552B1F8DD4E2B1B8EBB.description: Illustrate how all cell organelles work together by describing the step-by-step process of the translation of an mRNA strand into a protein and its subsequent processing by organelles so that the protein is appropriately packaged, labeled, and eventually exported by the cell

1F8E25F708874B749C2E82EA223BAC6C.description: Describe the functions of all major cell organelles, including nucleus, ER, RER, Golgi apparatus, ribosome, mitochondria, microtubules, microfilaments, lysosomes, centrioles, and cell membrane

C4A900E27F704358B3BE37135710A1B0.description: Explain the functions of unique plant structures, including the cell wall, chloroplasts, and large central vacuole

2416D413CFB6478F99747D0D53B75D0A.description: Compare and contrast animal and plant cells.

FC74EA24A5EA4036BE33AD47485A2482.description: Analyze the similarities and differences among (a) plant versus animal cells and (b) eukaryotic versus prokaryotic cells

EB079C1CF9934782B102BA31335356C7.description: Describe the general structure and function(s), including common functional groups, of monosaccharides, disaccharides, polysaccharides, carbohydrates, fatty acids, glycerol, glycerides, lipids, amino acids, dipeptides, polypeptides, proteins, andnucleic acids

C7624B2811BB41AAB36B80A19687DBA5.description: Explain the fundamental principles of the pH scale and the consequences of having the different concentrations of hydrogen and hydroxide ions

9915B74AF25440839AD1989F74E2F5B6.description: Define and explain the unique properties of water that are essential to living organisms

1DC6657F57464129A0A1D05904FA2416.description: Describe how the bonding between atoms forms molecules (polar covalent, nonpolar covalent, ionic, hydrogen)

051E413F40F34DF39DB76ACE36098042.description: Describe the difference between ions and atoms and the importance of ions in biological processes

E3DF2F4F74F040ADBF1E842A5B9A8A93.description: Describe the function of a valance electron in forming bonds

D0F923E45ADC435EBF687C55AAC0504D.description: Identify subatomic particles and describe how they are arranged in atoms

2A4065083B9540F7897ED9F5DD99EE20.description: Define and provide examples of each level of organization (e.g., biosphere, biome, ecosystem, community, population, multicellular organism, organ system, organ, tissue, cell, organelle, molecule, atom, subatomic particle)

AE7186B30E0147B3AAF75B20454ACC89.description: Describe the biological criteria that need to be met in order for an organism to be considered alive (8 major characteristics)

210173B08D7C40549C8BC32F4B4CC629.description: Identify the difference between an abiotic and biotic entity

63FD5A10AAE74CABB81AB2BA7C424021.description: Explain how the contributions of basic science drive the potential of applied science (e.g., advantages found in nature can be emulated for our own benefit/product development, such as observations of gecko feet suggesting new adhesives; understanding of basic cell biology leading to cancer treatments)

A714E2B530344DC08428CB7A23506481.description: Compare the goals and procedures followed in basic science with the goals and procedures of applied science and technology; discuss the important contributions of each and how citizens need to understand the ramifications of funding both endeavors

C01BFCC830FC426CBE4AE0DC2A35C0E5.description: Use a variety of appropriate sources (e.g., Internet, scientific journals) to retrieve relevant information; cite references properly

69519EBEE7C745CB90757BB2CD369DA0.description: Explain why all scientific knowledge is subject to change as new evidence becomes available to the scientific community

39E3F684D7724A8EB750F29CCA3CF4A7.description: Explain why scientific explanations must meet certain criteria (e.g., be consistent with experimental/observational evidence about nature, be open to critique and modification, be subject to peer review, use ethical reporting methods and procedures)

93AA6F9E59B54CEEA15E6AD7DC77862D.description: Recognize and apply criteria that scientists use to evaluate the validity of scientific claims and theories

BCD6853CF18445E5BCFB1284C0CBB13F.description: Assess how scientific and technological progress has affected other fields of study, careers, and aspects of everyday life

7B9E57CE02AD4B4C86F2B89267F8C9FF.description: Describe the fundamental assumptions of science

47A79E633A8A4F00925589F2ADECB758.description: Use graphical models, mathematical models, and simple statistical models to express patterns and relationships determined from sets of scientific data

8E2721A49E1F47BF9C73DA5CB092AE11.description: Calculate the mean of a set of values

458E0934867844408811192F927C2432.description: Safely use laboratory equipment and techniques when conducting scientific investigations

32467AA3AD5A4402A412D8A749A184A4.description: Write and speak effectively to present and explain scientific results, using appropriate terminology and graphics

90A12E59EB5E46A58744D817A70A3229.description: Collect, organize, and analyze data accurately and precisely (e.g., using scientific techniques and mathematics in experiments)

06366368C71142C980791AD227C73E2B.description: Manipulate variables in experiments using appropriate procedures (e.g., controls, multiple trials)

8129F1CB9BBD46C8A057AFEE4F4ABDD5.description: Identify and clarify biological research questions and design experiments
